awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: A Meta-Game Theoretic Approach to Cyber-Physical Co-Design of Secure and Resilient Control Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The increasing reliance on computer and communication technologies exposes control systems to cyber security threats. The physical systems can now be attacked through cyberspace. Emerging sophisticated attacks can exploit zero-day vulnerabilities, persist in the system for long periods of time, and advance stealthily to achieve their attack goals. Protection and prevention against such attacks are not always possible, and a paradigm shift to emphasize resilience of a control system is the overarching objective for safeguarding control systems to protect nation's critical infrastructures. The major challenge for designing secure and resilient cyber-physical control system is the lack of scientific foundations, and quantitative methods to provide a systematic guideline for large-scale cyber-physical interactions. To this end, the project aims to establish a meta-game system theory, and develop computational and design methodologies for cyber-physical co-design problems.

Game-theoretic tools serve as an appropriate way to interconnect systems from multiple domains into one single framework to address security and resilience issues of highly integrated CPS. This project investigates a meta-game framework as a new paradigm to compose heterogeneous system components to design their interactions to achieve functional security and resiliency properties. Through developing security-aware controllers and impact-aware proactive cyber defense mechanism, this project creates a system co-design paradigm based on the meta-game framework, which captures the system properties of robustness, security, and resilience in one single framework, and provides fundamental principles to characterize their tradeoffs. The analytical framework will lead to the development of a cyber-physical mechanism design theory to provide a solid foundation for achieving optimal cyber-physical integration for control systems. The developed analytical and design tools will allow the prediction of unexpected outcomes of system integrations, the mitigation of the impact of cyber attacks on control systems, and the cost-effective operation and design of resilient CPS.

por.por_cntn:
The increasing reliance on computer and communication technologies exposes control systems to cyber security threats. The physical systems can now be attacked through cyberspace. Emerging sophisticated attacks can exploit zero-day vulnerabilities, persist in the system for long periods of time, and advance stealthily to achieve their attack goals. Protection and prevention against such attacks are not always possible, and a paradigm shift to emphasize the resilience of a control system is the overarching objective for safeguarding control systems to protect a nation’s critical infrastructures. This project has addressed the major challenge for designing a secure and resilient cyber-physical control system by establishing scientific foundations, and quantitative methods to provide a systematic guideline for large-scale cyber-physical interactions. This project has created a meta-game system theory and developed computational and design methodologies for cyber-physical co-design problems. The meta-game theoretic approach enables capturing the system properties of robustness, security, and resilience in one single framework, and provides fundamental principles to characterize their tradeoffs. The developed analytical and design tools have allowed the prediction of unexpected outcomes of system integrations, the mitigation of the impact of cyber attacks on control systems, and the cost-effective operation and design of resilient CPS.

 

This project has developed a set of powerful and versatile game-theoretic tools to establish scientific co-design principles for integrating cyber and physical systems in a holistic manner. The methodologies in this project provide a holistic and interdisciplinary approach to the secure and resilient design of CPS, bridging the gap between multiple disciplines such as computer science, control, communications, and economics. The PI has integrated cyber security models and parameters into the design of resilient control systems at the physical layer to achieve fast, efficient, adaptive, and self-configurable resilient control systems. At the same time, this project has developed impact-aware proactive cyber defense mechanisms to effectively disrupt and deter sophisticated and persistent attacks, while minimizing their impact on its usability and control systems. The research team has created a system co-design paradigm using meta-game frameworks to analyze the tradeoffs among the robustness, security, and resiliency properties of CPS.  This approach has led to a mechanism design theory to provide a solid foundation for achieving optimal cyber-physical integration for control systems.

 

The developed theory has been broadly applicable to multiple application domains including transportation, industrial automation, and power grid. In particular, we have developed a dynamic proactive defense mechanism to minimize the impact of the adversary on the cyber-physical networks of industrial control systems. The defense algorithms have been tested on a virtual SCADA testbed and on a large-scale networked digital control system in a nuclear power plant (NPP).  We have shown that the autonomous defense mechanism can increase the success rate of thwarting cyberattacks by 41% and decrease the physical risk by 38%. The developed tool has shown to be capable of learning the adversary behaviors quickly within 5 steps of interactions and significantly preventing an expected loss of 72 million USD due to core damage.

 

 

 The PI has integrated research into several undergraduate and graduate courses and student capstone projects.  This project has trained 4 Ph.D. students. Two of them have graduated and become assistant professors. They continue working on the security and resilience of cyber-physical systems and creating educational and outreach activities in their institutions. The project has also trained two undergraduate students each year as part of the NYU summer undergraduate research program. The results have been disseminated via publications, workshops, tutorials, and online tools. The course materials and software tools developed in the project have been made accessible online.
